pdqninja.pdq
Interface Splittable

All Known Implementing Classes:
PDQFileInputStream, PDQFileReader, PDQMap, PDQMultimap, PDQSet, PDQSortedMap, PDQSortedMultimap
public interface Splittable

A class implements the Splittable interface to indicate that it can be divided into smaller instances.

The cornerstones of the PDQ computation model is the ability to divide input data into smaller chunks that can be processed efficiently, and subsequently, the ability to merge smaller chunks of output to create complete data. The PDQ programming model further requires that the splitting of input, as well as merging of output, must be the responsibility of respective data structures, which frees the programmer from the need of incorporating this computation model in their code.

The Splittable interface indicates that an object can be splitted into smaller sizes. A splittable class implements the getSplits() method that returns an Iterator for the splits.

The PDQ library will always call the getSplits function from a sequential context, therefore, the implementing class does not have to ensure thread-safety in this method.

See Also:
Mergeable

Method Summary
 Iterator<?> getSplits()
          Returns an iterator for the splits of this object.
 

Method Detail

getSplits

Iterator<?> getSplits()
Returns an iterator for the splits of this object.

The PDQ library asks a splittable object to deliver splits. It is the responsibility of the implementing class to manage the lifetime of the returned object.

The class does not have to implement the Iterator.remove() method for the returned Iterator. The PDQ library will always call this method from a sequential context, therefore, the implementing class does not have to ensure thread-safety in this method.

Returns:
an iterator for the splits of this object
